(Also see the Randoop Plug-in Manual.)

Compiling, testing, releasing, etc.

Prerequisites for compiling and testing:

  • Java 5.0 or greater
  • Eclipse 3.5 (Galileo) or Eclipse 3.6 (Helios)
  • Plug-in Development Environment for Eclipse
  • SWTBot for Eclipse

Setup Eclipse

First, you will need to download Eclipse or install the required features to your pre-existing Eclipse installation.

Download a New Eclipse Installation

Visit the Eclipse Downloads page and install 'Eclipse Classic.' Next, follow the instuctions below to install SWTBot from its update site. The Classic distribution already comes packaged with the Plug-in Development Environment and sources for many Eclipse plug-ins.

Install Required Add-ons

If you already have Eclipse installed, you can install the necessary features in a few easy steps:

  • Install The Eclipse Plug-in Development Environment
    1. Go to Help > Install New Software...
    2. Select the update site for your Eclipse version from the pull down list. For Helios this is http://download.eclipse.org/releases/helios
    3. Check Eclipse Plug-in Development Environment from the 'General Purpose Tools' category.
    4. Press Next to install the feature
  • Install SWTBot
    1. Go to Help > Install New Software...
    2. Add the appropriate SWTBot update-site for your Eclipse version to the available repositories
    3. Select all plug-ins except for 'SWTBot for GEF Testing'
    4. Press Next to install the features

Compiling Randoop Plug-in

Make a local clone of the Randoop repository in your Eclipse workspace folder. Open Eclipse, and import the projects 'randoop,' 'plugin,' 'plugin.feature,' 'plugin.updateSite,' 'plugin.tests,' and 'plugin.experimental' from the repository. To do this:

  1. Go to File > Import...
  2. Select Existing projects into Workspace, click 'Next'
  3. Select the working directory of your cloned Randoop repository as the root directory
  4. Check 'randoop' from the list and click 'Finish'
  5. Repeat these steps for the 'plugin,' 'plugin.feature,' 'plugin.updateSite,' 'plugin.tests,' and 'plugin.experimental' folders in your clone's working directory.

After adding all projects, you may need to run Project > Clean... to get the projects to compile.

Running Plug-in Tests

In the fragment plugin.tests, run each launch configuration in the 'launchConfigurations' folder.

Modifying the manual

To modify the Randoop manual, edit directly the HTML files:

  • plugin/doc/index.html has the user manual.
  • plugin/doc/dev.html has the developer manual

Then, run under Randoop's home directory: 

% make plugin-manual

Making a new distribution

  1. Ensure that the field RANDOOP_JAR equals "randoop.jar" and not "../bin" in the class randoop.plugin.RandoopPlugin
  2. If necessary, re-export the randoop jar to the plugin folder
  3. Right click on the 'plugin' project and select Export from the context menu
  4. Select Deployable features, click 'Next'
  5. Check 'randoop' from the list of available features
  6. Under the 'Destination' tab, select 'Directory' and browse for the 'plugin.updateSite' directory
  7. Under the 'Options' tab:
    1. Check 'Package as individual JAR archives'
    2. Check 'Generate metadata repository'
    3. Check 'Categorize repository' and browse for 'category.xml' in the 'plugin.updateSite' directory
    4. Check 'Allow for binary cycles in target platform'
    5. Uncheck all other options
